Authors:
Yanis Bouchenak-Khelladi, Jasper Alexander Slingsby, George
Anthony Verboom, William J Bond
Title:
DIVERSIFICATION OF C4 GRASSES (POACEAE) DOES NOT COINCIDE
WITH THEIR ECOLOGICAL DOMINANCE
Keywords:
evolutionary history, ecological dominance, angiosperms,
grasses (Poaceae), phylogenetics, diversification, dating
Abstract:
Premise of the study: The radiation and rise to ecological
dominance of a lineage are distinct phenomena, which are driven by
different processes. For example, it has been shown, using
paleoecological data that the Cretaceous angiosperm radiation did not
coincide with their rise to dominance. Using a phylogenetic approach, we
explore the evolution of C4 grasses and evaluate whether the
diversification of this group and its rise to ecological dominance in
the late Miocene are decoupled. Methods: We assembled a matrix including
675 PACMAD grass species for 2,784 characters (ITS and ndhF). Using
these data, a molecular dating analysis was performed using three
fossils for calibrations. We coded species as C3 vs.Â C4 and
reconstructed ancestral states under maximum likelihood. We used BiSSE
to test whether rates of diversification are correlated with
photosynthetic pathway and whether the radiation of C4 lineages preceded
or coincided with their rise to ecological dominance from about 10 Ma.
Key results: C4 grass lineages first originated around 35 Ma at the
Eocene/Oligocene transition. Accelerated diversification of C4 lineages
did not coincide with their rise to ecological dominance. Conclusions:
C4-dominated grasslands have expanded only from the Late Miocene and
Pliocene. The initial diversification of their biotic elements can be
tracked back as far as the Eocene-Oligocene transition. We suggest that
shifts in taxonomic diversification and ecological dominance were
stimulated by different factors, as it has been the case for the early
angiosperms in the Cretaceous.
